citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Eight birds have died since the prior USDA inspection on 26September2023 (1 peahen, 1 cockatiel, 1 budgerigar, 1 red-
front macaw, 1 Senegal parrot, 1 eclectus parrot, 1 coturnix quail, and 1 button quail). Via phone communications, the
Attending Veterinarian (AV) was only aware of the loss of the Senegal parrot and had not been notified of the other 7
deaths at the time of this inspection.
Not notifying the AV of the deaths of animals undermines the authority of the AV by not allowing the provision of
preventative or acute medical care nor permitting proper veterinary investigation into the causes of death.
The regulations state that each dealer and exhibitor shall assure that the AV has appropriate authority to ensure the
provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use.

Disposition records for 5 birds that died on the premises were incomplete. The dates of these animals' deaths were not
documented in the facility's record of animals on hand (1 peahen, 1 coturnix quail, 1 Senegal parrot, 1 cockatiel and 1
budgerigar).
Not properly documenting the disposition of animals no longer at a facility can confound attempts to trace animal
movements and evaluate disease epidemiology.
The regulations state that every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly
disclose the following information concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned,
held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or
otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor: the date of purchase, acquisition, sale, or disposal of the animal(s).
Correct by 01December2023.

The Attending Veterinarian (AV) included an acclimation statement in the facility’s Bird Environmental Enrichment
Program (BEEP). The BEEP states that “All birds except those listed (1 African Grey listed – housed indoors) are
acclimated to the weather and temperature conditions of this area and may be housed outdoors year-round, provided they
are given supplemental heat through a heat lamp, heater, brooder panel or another heat source when temperatures fall
below 40 degrees. There must be enough heat sources for every bird in the enclosure to have access to supplemental
heat.” However, multiple enclosures housing a total of 79 birds did not contain adequate heat sources during the past two
nights’ low temperatures of 25F and 33F degrees.
--enclosure housing 2 zebra finches and 7 diamond doves (9 birds) contained no heat source.
--enclosure housing 6 pigeons, 5 chukar and 1 ringneck dove (12 birds) contained no heat source.
--enclosure housing 12 macaws had only 5 heat lamps.
--enclosure containing 8 conures and 2 macaws (10 birds) contained only 4 heat lamps.
--enclosure containing two macaws had only 1 heat lamp.
--enclosure housing 3 African Greys, 1 Senegal, 8 lovebirds and 2 coturnix quail (14 birds) had only 3 heat lamps, none of
which were where the ground-dwelling 2 quail live.
--enclosure housing multiple species of birds (20 birds) had only 3 heat lamps, none of which were where the ground-
dwelling 3 pheasants and 3 button quail live.
Not providing adequate heat supplementation for every bird when temperatures are below 40F, as required by the AV in
order to live outdoors, poses a significant risk to the health of the birds, especially those lower in the social hierarchy in
the enclosures.
The regulations state that birds may not be housed in outdoor facilities unless the air, humidity and temperature ranges do
not adversely affect bird health and comfort.
Correct as soon as possible but no later than 13December2023.

Three enclosures housing a total of 28 birds did not contain adequate shelter from inclement weather and/or winter winds.
--enclosure housing 12 macaws had insufficient shelter for protection from wind, precipitation, and/or cold temperatures.
The sheltered area contained a roof and only two sides, leaving two sides exposed to the prevailing winter conditions and
wind.
--enclosure housing 3 African Greys, 1 Senegal, 8 lovebirds and 2 coturnix quail (14 birds) did not contain adequate side
walls and shelters to protect from winter wind.
--enclosure housing 2 macaws did not contain adequate shelter to protect from winter wind.
Birds unable to protect themselves from cold winter conditions and winds are subjected to excessive discomfort and may
be at increased risk of illness and death, especially those birds lower in the social hierarchy in the enclosures.
The regulations state that outdoor housing facilities must provide adequate shelter, appropriate to the species and
physical condition of the birds, for the local climatic conditions to protect the birds from any adverse weather conditions.
Shelters must be adequately ventilated in hot weather and have one or more separate areas of shade or other effective
protection that is large enough to comfortably contain all the birds at one time and prevent their discomfort from direct
sunlight, precipitation, or wind.
Correct as soon as possible but no later than 13December2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2)  Critical Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Eight birds have died since the prior USDA inspection on 26September2023 (1 peahen, 1 cockatiel, 1 budgerigar, 1 red-
front macaw, 1 Senegal parrot, 1 eclectus parrot, 1 coturnix quail, and 1 button quail). Via phone communications, the 
Attending Veterinarian (AV) was only aware of the loss of the Senegal parrot and had not been notified of the other 7 
deaths at the time of this inspection.  
 
Not notifying the AV of the deaths of animals undermines the authority of the AV by not allowing the provision of 
preventative or acute medical care nor permitting proper veterinary investigation into the causes of death.  
 
The regulations state that each dealer and exhibitor shall assure that the AV has appropriate authority to ensure the 
provision of adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use. 
2.75(b)(1)(v) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Disposition records for 5 birds that died on the premises were incomplete. The dates of these animals' deaths were not 
documented in the facility's record of animals on hand (1 peahen, 1 coturnix quail, 1 Senegal parrot, 1 cockatiel and 1 
budgerigar). 
 
Not properly documenting the disposition of animals no longer at a facility can confound attempts to trace animal 
movements and evaluate disease epidemiology.  
 
The regulations state that every exhibitor shall make, keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly 
disclose the following information concerning animals other than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, 
held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or 
otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor: the date of purchase, acquisition, sale, or disposal of the animal(s).  
 
Correct by 01December2023.

3.152(a) 
   
Facilities, outdoor 
The Attending Veterinarian (AV) included an acclimation statement in the facility’s Bird Environmental Enrichment 
Program (BEEP). The BEEP states that “All birds except those listed (1 African Grey listed – housed indoors) are 
acclimated to the weather and temperature conditions of this area and may be housed outdoors year-round, provided they 
are given supplemental heat through a heat lamp, heater, brooder panel or another heat source when temperatures fall 
below 40 degrees. There must be enough heat sources for every bird in the enclosure to have access to supplemental 
heat.” However, multiple enclosures housing a total of 79 birds did not contain adequate heat sources during the past two 
nights’ low temperatures of 25F and 33F degrees.  
 
--enclosure housing 2 zebra finches and 7 diamond doves (9 birds) contained no heat source. 
--enclosure housing 6 pigeons, 5 chukar and 1 ringneck dove (12 birds) contained no heat source.  
--enclosure housing 12 macaws had only 5 heat lamps.  
--enclosure containing 8 conures and 2 macaws (10 birds) contained only 4 heat lamps. 
--enclosure containing two macaws had only 1 heat lamp. 
--enclosure housing 3 African Greys, 1 Senegal, 8 lovebirds and 2 coturnix quail (14 birds) had only 3 heat lamps, none of 
which were where the ground-dwelling 2 quail live.  
--enclosure housing multiple species of birds (20 birds) had only 3 heat lamps, none of which were where the ground-
dwelling 3 pheasants and 3 button quail live.  
 
Not providing adequate heat supplementation for every bird when temperatures are below 40F, as required by the AV in 
order to live outdoors, poses a significant risk to the health of the birds, especially those lower in the social hierarchy in 
the enclosures.  
 
The regulations state that birds may not be housed in outdoor facilities unless the air, humidity and temperature ranges do 
not adversely affect bird health and comfort.  
 
Correct as soon as possible but no later than 13December2023. 
3.152(b) 
   
Facilities, outdoor 
Three enclosures housing a total of 28 birds did not contain adequate shelter from inclement weather and/or winter winds.  
 
--enclosure housing 12 macaws had insufficient shelter for protection from wind, precipitation, and/or cold temperatures. 
The sheltered area contained a roof and only two sides, leaving two sides exposed to the prevailing winter conditions and 
wind.  
--enclosure housing 3 African Greys, 1 Senegal, 8 lovebirds and 2 coturnix quail (14 birds) did not contain adequate side 
walls and shelters to protect from winter wind.  
--enclosure housing 2 macaws did not contain adequate shelter to protect from winter wind.

Birds unable to protect themselves from cold winter conditions and winds are subjected to excessive discomfort and may 
be at increased risk of illness and death, especially those birds lower in the social hierarchy in the enclosures.  
 
The regulations state that outdoor housing facilities must provide adequate shelter, appropriate to the species and 
physical condition of the birds, for the local climatic conditions to protect the birds from any adverse weather conditions. 
Shelters must be adequately ventilated in hot weather and have one or more separate areas of shade or other effective 
protection that is large enough to comfortably contain all the birds at one time and prevent their discomfort from direct 
sunlight, precipitation, or wind.  
 
Correct as soon as possible but no later than 13December2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
